The last two exercises in MoP 8.2 (Bijectivity) apparently require 27 and 256 separate cases to be considered - clearly not the right approach, and the course author indeed hints we should find a different way: "but with even more (frankly, way too many ….) cases to check."

So I thought I would challenge myself and create a lemma which established that any function from a finite set to the same finite set is surjective if it is injective:

injective f:S→S  ⟹  surjective f \text{injective } f:S \to S \implies \text{surjective } finjective f:S→S⟹surjective f.

Question: I'd welcome guidance on the proof strategy, in particular the ease of implementation as a Lean lemma using beginner level tactics.

I think a good way to do this is by induction:

Base Case : set with cardinality 111

If a function f:{a}→{a}f: \{a\} \to \{a\}f:{a}→{a} is injective, then it is surjective. To show this we can consider all the cases of the image set, which happen to be just aaa. We know fff maps as f(a)=af(a)=af(a)=a and so for every element of the image we have shown there is an element of the domain which maps to it.

In Lean I think I can use cases to do this.

Induction Step : set with cardinality n to cardinality (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)

The induction hypothesis is: "for a set with cardinality nnn, if a function f:S→Sf : S \to Sf:S→S is injective, then it is surjective".

We need to prove: "for a set with cardinality (n+1)(n+1)(n+1), if a function f:S→Sf : S \to Sf:S→S is injective, then it is surjective".

In a pen-and-paper proof, I'd split that set into two sets, one set AAA with cardinality nnn and one set BBB with cardinality 111. Then we would say, since the function is injective over A∪BA \cup BA∪B as well as over AAA that means the new element of BBB does not map to AAA, and so must map to BBB. Since the function is known to be surjective over AAA, and we've shown it maps BBB to BBB, then it is surjective over A∪BA \cup BA∪B.

If this is a good approach, the challenge for me is how to do this in Lean. I have no idea!

However - by this point in MoP, sets have not been introduced, so the author must have another method in mind?
The problem is, a function A∪B→A∪BA \cup B \to A \cup BA∪B→A∪B does not necessarily induce a function A→AA \to AA→A, so your pen-and-paper proof is invalid.

I want to be sure I understand. Is the following sentence from my original post the one with the error?

since the function is injective over A∪BA \cup BA∪B as well as over AAA
Lets say that AAA is {T}\{\text{T}\}{T} and BBB is {F}\{\text{F}\}{F}, then A∪BA \cup BA∪B would be Bool\text{Bool}Bool. Our function is boolean not. How do you use the inductive hypothesis here?

rzeta0 said:

I want to be sure I understand. Is the following sentence from my original post the one with the error?

since the function is injective over A∪BA \cup BA∪B as well as over AAA

What do you mean "injective over AAA"? Before, you were using it as "the function, seen as a function A→AA \to AA→A, is injective" (this is the requirement for the induction hypothesis), but here, the function does not necessarily map AAA to AAA.

My apologies for the sloppy language "injective over A" should be "the function A -> A is injective".

I need to go away and rethink all this. Thanks for your help.

(Still pen-and-paper, I have no idea how to go about doing this in Lean, and MoP is one of the tutorials I have not tried to follow so far)

So you assume B={b}B=\{b\}B={b}, and some function fff is injective from A∪BA\cup BA∪B to itself; thus, it injects AAA to some other set A′A'A′, and maps bbb to some b′b'b′; but you cannot assume b=b′b=b'b=b′ (or, equivalently, A=A′A=A'A=A′).

So if you want to keep your induction hypothesis (about functions from a set to itself), you will have to compose your function with a well-chosen bijection so that the result maps AAA to AAA and BBB to BBB, then use appropriate results (which I assume you already have) about such compositions.

Here's my proof strategy:

proof

  • Define a finite type as "there is no injection N→α\mathbb{N} \to \alphaN→α".

  • Show that injective functions have a left inverse.

  • Let x∈αx \in \alphax∈α, and consider the function defined by n↦fn(x)n \mapsto f^n(x)n↦fn(x).
    Since this is a function N→α\mathbb{N} \to \alphaN→α, it can't be injective, so there exists m≠nm \ne nm=n for which fm(x)=fn(x)f^m(x) = f^n(x)fm(x)=fn(x).
    Since fff is injective, this means f∣m−n∣(x)=xf^{|m - n|}(x) = xf∣m−n∣(x)=x.
    Since m≠nm \ne nm=n we have ∣m−n∣≠0|m - n| \ne 0∣m−n∣=0 so f(f∣m−n∣−1(x))=xf(f^{|m - n| - 1}(x)) = xf(f∣m−n∣−1(x))=x.
    Since f(something)=xf(\text{something}) = xf(something)=x for arbitrary xxx, fff is surjective.

  • Bonus: Show a type is finite iff there exists a docs#List containing all the elements. This will make it easy to show specific types are finite.

Thanks @Kevin Buzzard

For this I wanted to challenge myself to see if I could (1) write a pen-n-paper proof, and (2) do it in Lean too.

A challenge because I didn't do maths at university so this would be a test to see if my self-teaching was working... (clearly not! :)

I would say that this is a pretty difficult lemma for a beginner to try by themselves, not least because even the concept of finiteness is difficult to work with formally. For example: how might we imagine Lean defines what it means for a type to be finite? We could imagine demanding that the type bijects with the type Fin n := {0,1,2,...,n-1} for some n. This definition would work fine. Now using this definition, how do we define the size of a finite set? Of course informally we never give the definition of size, the concept of size is "obvious". But Lean wants a definition. So we could define the size of X to be "take the n for which X bijects with Fin n and this is the size of X". But then Lean says "well how do we know which n to take?" and we could just say "OK well use the axiom of choice to choose such an n". But now when we start trying to prove things about sizes of sets we run into the problem that we really need to know that such an n is unique. So we go back to our definition of size and say "OK define the size of X to be the unique n such that X bijects with Fin n and then Lean says "well how do you know that n is unique?" and we say "well this is obvious because if a and b are different naturals then obviously Fin a can't biject with Fin b" and Lean says "why" and we say "well because they have different sizes" and Lean says "yeah but this argument is circular".

None of this would show up in an informal proof, even in a university course; it would all be swept under the carpet. But there is really an issue here, and when formalizing one has to deal with these issues. Mathlib has proved hundreds if not thousands of theorems about finite sets and some of these are really hard-won; some of the proofs in Data.Finset.Basic are very clever and subtle. I encourage my undergraduates to stay away from finiteness at the beginning. If you're wandering off on your own, I would strongly recommend not wandering into the world of finiteness. If you still want to, then I would encourage you to try and figure out how to prove that every finite set has a unique size i.e. how to make Lean happy in the story above. If you can do that then probably you're ready to prove that surjective implies injective.

Thanks Kevin - I value your thoughts and advice. For this I will use the surjective_of_finite and do your suggested simpler challenge.

Personally, I am finding that the extra rigour and detail in thinking required to do Lean proofs helps me better understand pen-n-paper proofs - albeit with simpler examples than this one.

(One downside I've found with Lean exercises is that"goal-chasing" where I can solve the proof by iteratively resolving the local goal and not really thinking about the macro proof).
rzeta0 has marked this topic as resolved.

"well this is obvious because if a and b are different naturals then obviously Fin a can't biject with Fin b" and Lean says "why" and we say "well because they have different sizes"

A more reasonable approach is to apply swaps to construct an isomorphism between a function and smaller parts. That's the approach I used to count permutations:

def some_iso {n: Nat}: Perm n.succ.succ ≃ (Perm n.succ × Fin n.succ.succ) :=
  { to := λp =>
      let last := Fin.last n.succ
      let s := p.trans $ swapPerm last (p.to last)
      let h := by simp [s, Equiv.trans, swapPerm, swap, last]
      ⟨dentPerm s h, p.to last⟩
    inv := λ⟨p,i⟩ =>
      (bumpPerm p).trans $ swapPerm i (Fin.last _)
    leftInv := λp => by
      refine Equiv.ext _ _ λx => ?_
      show
        (swap (p.to $ Fin.last _) (Fin.last _) $
          if x = Fin.last _ then x
          else bump $ dent $
            swap (Fin.last _) (p.to $ Fin.last _) (p.to $ bump $ dent x))
        = p.to x

      if h: x = Fin.last _ then
        simp [h, swap_eq_left]
      else
        simp [h, bump_after_dent h]
        show
          (swap (p.to (Fin.last _)) (Fin.last _) $
            bump $ dent $ swap (Fin.last _) (p.to $ Fin.last _) (p.to x))
          = p.to x

        have ne: p.to x ≠ p.to (Fin.last _) := Equiv.to_ne_of_ne _ h
        if h2: p.to x = Fin.last _ then
          simp [h2, swap_eq_right, bump_after_dent (h2 ▸ ne.symm)]
        else
          simp [h2, ne, swap_eq_same, bump_after_dent h2]
    rightInv :=
      λ⟨p,i⟩ => by
        refine (Prod.mk.injEq _ _ _ _).mpr ⟨?perm, ?swap⟩
        case swap =>
          simp [Equiv.trans, swapPerm, bumpPerm, swap_eq_left]
        case perm =>
          refine Equiv.ext _ _ λx => ?_
          simp [Equiv.trans, swapPerm, bumpPerm, dentPerm]
          simp [bump_ne_last, dent_after_bump, swap_eq_left, swap_invol, swap_comm]
  }

(not an #mwe at all, requires a couple of definitions and lemmas to work)

I wonder if there's a simpler way that does not require playing with swaps, restrictions and extensions, but judging from your comment life is not that easy (even when ignoring a natural desire to keep things constructive).

Kevin is right that this is surprisingly difficult. Even the exercise he suggested--proving that every finite set has a unique size--is pretty hard. If you want to do a pencil-and-paper proof that is similar to the problem you were working on, but a bit easier, I suggest the following: Suppose f:S→Sf : S \to Sf:S→S and fff is injective. For a set AAA contained in SSS, say that AAA is closed under fff if ∀x∈A,f(x)∈A\forall x \in A, f(x) \in A∀x∈A,f(x)∈A. Now prove that for every finite set AAA contained in SSS, if AAA is closed under fff then ∀y∈A,∃x∈A,f(x)=y\forall y \in A, \exists x \in A, f(x) = y∀y∈A,∃x∈A,f(x)=y. This can be done by induction on the number of elements of AAA, using a strategy that is similar to what you started with. Note that if you can prove this, then the theorem you wanted follows: if SSS is finite, then you can apply the theorem to SSS, and you get the conclusion that fff is surjective.
